question: In models of mechanically induced skin fibrosis, does inhibition of focal adhesion signaling (e.g., via fibroblast-specific FAK knockout or small-molecule FAK inhibitors) increase scar formation? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Small-molecule inhibition of FAK blocks these effects in human cells and reduces scar formation in vivo through attenuated MCP-1 signaling and inflammatory cell recruitment.
content.source_2: Taken together, these results indicate that physical force drives fibrosis via inflammatory FAK–ERK–MCP-1 signaling and that pharmacologic strategies targeting FAK can enhance the coupling of mechanical stress to pathological scar formation.
content.source_3: Fibroblast-specific FAK knockout mice have substantially less inflammation and fibrosis than control mice in a model of hypertrophic scar formation.
content.source_4: In contrast to expectations, MCP-1 knockout mice displayed pronounced hypertrophic scarring under mechanical loading, suggesting that disruption of this chemokine pathway permits mechanical strain to be converted into fibrotic remodeling.
